trial_identification.studytitle: Quantifying the effect of the sedative alprazolam on brain electrical activity using the Brain Anaesthesia Response monitor
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Quantifying the effect of alprazolam on brain electrical activity in healthy males using the BAR monitor

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

interventions.comparator: resting EEG prior to drug treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in BAR index (mean pole location)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: BAR index recorded for 5 minutes every hour for 3 hours following drug administration

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes from baseline in relative delta, theta, alpha, beta and gamma power will be assessed using repeated measures ANOVA.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed every hour for 3 hours following drug administration

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: non-smoker, no history of anxiety, depression or other psychiatric disorder, no history of epilepsy or other neurological disorder known to affect resting EEG
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: consumption of any pharmaceutical product/medicine in last 30 days, consumption of vitamin complex or herbal extract withion last 30 days, history of alcohol or drug abuse

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is designed to evaluate a new method for monitoring the effects of sedatives on the brain's electrical activity. The method involves a sophisticated, physiologically motivated, algorithm for the analysis of the scalp recorded electroencephalogram.

contact.name: Associate Professor David TJ Liley
contact.address: Brain and Psychological Sciences Research Centre Swinburne University of Technology P.O. Box 218 Hawthorn VIC 3122
